column4: ok, for some reason i'm now seeing /dev/sda1 and /dev/sda2 when i plug in my ipod, but i can't mount either one b/c mount tells me neither is a valid block device...
if it makes any difference my ipod is a 4G (clickwheel) and was originally installed on Windows
open a terminal, run "dmesg | tail", and then plug in your ipod. you should see some messages pop up
specifically, you should see what dev node the ipod is given
yeah i got that...
http://dpaste.com/6753/
perhaps try /dev/sda2?
i've tried them all... mount always says not a valid block device
any other ideas?
you tried sda0 as well right? ls -l /dev/sd?? <- paste the output of that perhaps?
sda0 does not exist... only /dev/sda1 and /dev/sda2
you have gtkpod installed?
what does iTunes say about the filesystem of your iPod?
but you formatted it for windows, correct?
let me paste a little more from dmesg
here's what dmesg shows if i plug in the ipod then wait 30-60 seconds: http://dpaste.com/6755/
i'm googling that SCSI error, looks like a rare one
rejecting I/O to offline device?
0x50000 <- the error code.
looks like a very weird kernel bug. i'd start by using fsck to check the file system if you can

actually now that i look a little closer i think that's unrelated..... to "safely" unplug the ipod i rebooted it and disconnected while it was rebooting... i think that error is caused by the system trying to establish communication with the device # the ipod was connected as before i disconnected it
let me monitor dmesg a little longer while the ipod is disconnected before i plug it in again and see if these errors are related...
still around?
